While sustainable forestry practices in Canada are a step in the right direction, it is uncertain whether they will be enough to fully mitigate the environmental impact of logging in the long run. The forestry industry is still a significant driver of deforestation and habitat destruction, and even with sustainable practices in place, there will still be some impact on the environment.

That being said, sustainable forestry practices can go a long way in minimizing the environmental impact of logging. By using these practices, the forestry industry can help to maintain forest health and promote biodiversity, protect water quality, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Additionally, certification programs such as the Forest Stewardship Council and the Sustainable Forestry Initiative provide independent verification of sustainable forestry practices, which can give consumers confidence that the wood products they are buying are responsibly sourced.

Ultimately, it will require a combination of sustainable forestry practices, effective regulation, and public awareness and support to mitigate the environmental impact of logging in the long run. The Canadian government and other stakeholders will need to continue to work together to find solutions that balance economic development with environmental responsibility.
